sub_questions.sub_question_text: Draw a sketch map of Kongo Kingdom and locate the following chiefdoms: Mpemba, Nsundi, Mbamba, Soyo, Mpangu and Mbata.

The items (i-iv) consist of four sentences which form a complete historical meaning. One of the sentences is missing. Identify the missing sentence from the sentences given after each set of items and write its letter beside the item number.

(i) Germany need for colonies came later after Britain and France.
(ii) The entering of Germany in the scramble stimulated and heightened the scramble.
(iii) Carl Peters became champion for Germany colonization of Africa through GEACO.
(iv) ____________________

options.A: Carl Peters decided to call the Berlin conference to solve the competition problem.
options.B: Finally Namibia, Cameroon and Togo became Germany colonies.
options.C: Carl Peters presented the already signed treaties at the Berlin Conference in 1884/1885.
options.D: Carl Peter was part of the early explorers who pretended to be the mechanics.
options.E: After the Heligoland Treaty of 1890 Carl Peters became the first German Governor in East Africa.

sub_questions.sub_question_text:
(i) Transport and communication was essential during the colonial period.
(ii) Railways and roads were established running perpendicularly to the coast.
(iii) In some places feeder roads were constructed to facilitate transportation of raw materials and goods.
(iv) Such roads include ____________________

options.A: Iringa - Dodoma road, Lushoto - Mombo and Kondoa - Arusha road.
options.B: Moshi - Arusha and Tanga - Muheza roads.
options.C: Dar es Salaam - Dodoma - Singida - Mwanza road
options.D: Dar es Salaam - Tanga - Mombasa road.
options.E: Dar es Salaam - Morogoro - Iringa - Songea road.

sub_questions.sub_question_text:
(i) Reaction towards the imposition of colonialism in Africa took different responses.
(ii) Treaty making was one of the methods used by some African societies to maintain their freedom.
(iii) Other societies collaborated as a way to avoid war with Europeans.
(iv) ____________________

options.A: Those who collaborated were able to maintain their independence.
options.B: Regardless of which method opted no single African society accepted colonization.
options.C: The treaties were bogus because African societies knew the contents through their interpreters.
options.D: Where the missionaries were used in the signing of treaties, African interest was considered.
options.E: In East Africa most societies in Southern Tanganyika collaborated with Germany.

sub_questions.sub_question_text:
(i) Establishment of colonial economy in Africa went through stages.
(ii) ____________________
(iii) Bee wax, wild rubber, pigeon peas were among the commodities.
(iv) Other new export crops like cotton, sisal, coffee and rubber were introduced.

options.A: The first stage was creation, destruction and preservation.
options.B: The first stage was extraction of traditional commodities.
options.C: Commodities such as cloth, spirits, mirror, outdated guns came from the North.
options.D: Slaves, salt, dates and indigo were highly demanded in exchange with European commodities.
options.E: Establishment of strong colonial economy was halted by slave trade activities.

sub_questions.sub_question_text:
(i) One of the drawbacks of African nationalism in East Africa was religious conflicts.
(ii) The problem was more noted in Uganda than in German East Africa.
(iii) ____________________
(iv) In British East Africa the conflicts were more tribal than religious.

options.A: The conflict was between Buganda against Toro, Ankole and Nyoro.
options.B: The Moslems, Protestants, Catholics and the traditionalists each wanted to influence Kabaka.
options.C: The conflict led to the signing of the Buganda Agreement of 1900 as a solution to the problem.
options.D: To avoid more conflicts both the East African territories were put under the British through the 1890 Heligoland Treaty.
options.E: To avoid more conflicts Kabaka Mwanga of Buganda was deported to Mauritius.

sub_questions.sub_question_text:
Arrange the following statements in chronological order by writing numbers 1 to 5 beside the item number.

(i) Violence, intimidation and diplomacy were used by colonial powers in occupying different parts of Africa.

(ii) Colonial economy was then established so as to meet the requirements of colonialism such as the demand for raw materials and markets

(iii) Missionaries, explorers and traders came to Africa for the purpose of getting different information about the African continent.

(iv) Colonial political control was established over African territories through the use of different principles such as military, administrative and ideological principles.

(v) Chancellor Bismarck of Germany convened the Berlin Conference so as to partition Africa among the imperialist powers peacefully
